summary: This is a proposed protective order from the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case, issued by Judge Alison J. Nathan. It establishes confidentiality rules for materials produced from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Fund under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 17(c), designating them as 'Confidential Information' or potentially 'Highly Confidential' to protect privacy and prevent prejudicial pretrial publicity.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named as the defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) before the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Issued the proposed protective order, directing the parties to negotiate and submit it, and will oversee the confidentiality of materials from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Fund.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case in which Maxwell is the defendant, as evidenced by the issuance of this protective order in case 20 Cr. 330.

events.title: Issuance of Proposed Protective Order
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issued a proposed protective order regarding materials from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Fund produced under Fed. R. Crim. P. 17(c) in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court ordered production of materials from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Fund under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 17(c) for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.
These materials are designated as 'Confidential Information' to protect individual privacy, prevent prejudicial pretrial publicity, and limit disclosure to what is necessary for the trial.
The court retains discretion to designate certain materials as 'Highly Confidential' under the existing protective order (Dkt. No. 36).
The protective order applies to the Government, the defendant (Ghislaine Maxwell), and her criminal defense attorneys.
